award_title: High Bandwidth Hexapod for Hypersonic Flight Simulation
research_keywords: Hardware-in-the-loop,HWIL,hypersonic,Vibration,Testing,Guidance,flight motion simulator,CONTROL
abstract: ABSTRACT: Hypersonic flight environments can include vibration with high frequency spectral content that is difficult to simulate.This high frequency vibration may adversely affect the accuracy of guidance and control sensors, so it is very important to the Air Force Research Laboratory to be able to recreate the vibration in a way that allows sensor performance to be evaluated.Motion platforms such as the KHILS ISTAT facility have been built for this purpose, but current technology only partially addresses this need.Present frequency capability is limited to about 500 Hz, while 1000 Hz bandwidth would ideally be available.Dynamic Structures and Materials (DSM) believes that these needs can be met through a high frequency motion simulator that uses a parallel kinematic actuator (PKA).High performance linear motors will be used with a novel approach to construction of the joints to provide high performance, reliable motion simulation.This actuator will be combined with a flexible, open control architecture and high resolution sensors, resulting in a system that is maintainable and able to deliver the high acceleration and precision necessary for hypersonic flight vibration simulation.; BENEFIT: The most direct benefit of the proposed development effort is improved fidelity in hardware-in-the-loop simulations at the KHILS facility.This will lead to better accuracy and more confidence in the performance estimates for US interceptors and similar hypersonic vehicles.After successful deployment at KHILS, there will be other opportunities to apply this technology.There are other flight simulation facilities such as the ones at USAF AEDC that might benefit from a similar capability.While remaining compliant with ITAR and other restrictions on distribution, DSM will seek to market related products for high performance vehicle simulation; this is a well-developed industry that would benefit from the increased capability described.Hexapods have many applications outside vehicle simulation, so it may also be feasible to market similar devices for wire bonders or similar high speed assembly applications.

award_title: Next Generation, High Frequency, 6 DOF, HWIL Motion Simulator
research_keywords: HWIL,6 DOF,Motion Simulation,KHILS,guided weapon,High Frequency,AGWT
abstract: ABSTRACT: Etegent proposes a novel design to achieve reliable, 1000 Hz bandwidth 6 DOF motion simulation for HWIL testing of seeker and IMU systems at the AFRL KHILS facility at Eglin AFB. Etegent's design significantly uncouples actuators from the motion platform, reducing parasitic mass, actuator dynamic side loads, actuator attachment point wear and failure, and actuator power requirements.An integrated design optimization study will be conducted during Phase I to optimize the design across actuator EM and structural parameters, actuation load path stiffness, motion platform structural dynamics, and sensor and control system approaches. Real-time prognostics and sensor/actuator/structure monitoringand failure accommodation will be integrated into the system.; BENEFIT: Etegent's high frequency 6 DOF motion simulator will enable more accurate, reliable, full bandwidthHWIL simulation/evaluation of future hypersonic and kinetic energy kill vehicle systems, reducing development cost and time.

award_title: Dimensionally Stable HSC (DiSH) Booms for RF Antennas
research_keywords: Deployable RF antennas,Packaging Efficiency,high-strain composite structures
abstract: ABSTRACT: To address the need for CubeSat-compatible, dimensionally stable, high strain composite materials and booms for future RF antennas, Roccor proposes to develop DiSH technology. DiSHTM laminates are rollable to achieve high linear and volumetric compaction ratios and dimensionally stable to minimize deformations from temperature variations and on-orbit operations.  Further, DiSHTM laminates are designed to be compatible with a range of structural architectures from simple tape-spring and tube booms where cost and simplicity drive program goals or more complex structures (truss and tension-stabilized systems) when necessary.  During Phase I, Roccor and our RF system partner, ASTRA LLC, will focus on designing, manufacturing, and testing highly stable and electrically functional DiSH laminates.  Requirements will encompass all mechanical, electrical, magnetic, and thermal performance goals of interest to the Air Force.  From these requirements, a CubeSat-compatible point design for a DiSH boom system will be developed for testing during Phase II.; BENEFIT: The overarching Phase I objective is to conduct an preliminary design-analysis-fabrication-test loop for a DiSH Boom capable of meeting requirements for a variety of future Air Force RF antenna and instruments (e.g., magnetometer, E-field, dipole/loop, and communications antenna), and clearly identify engineering development risks that must be addressed to ultimately ensure adequate performance of these booms on-orbit.  The emphasis will be on proving that the unique combination of hybrid-fiber composite laminate designs and high-strain surface treatments can enable high-precision and stability in the deployed boom  far in excess of COTS systems on the market today  and with a simple and low-cost system design.  The anticipated result of Phase I is definition of a family of DiSH laminate designs capable of meeting a range of deployable RF instrument and antenna designs of interest to the Air Force, qualification of these designs through coupon thermal/mechanical testing and component RF transparency testing, and development of a conceptual design of a DiSH Boom system to be further developed during Phase II.  In addition to DoDs CubeSat RF antenna market discussed above, Roccor has identified two other markets where the proposed technology could have considerable impact: a) portable and man-packable deployable antennas for military ground troops and b) deployable apertures for communication satellites and space exploration vehicles.

award_title: High Refractive Index Hybrid Polysulfane Thermosets for IR Applications
research_keywords: IR polymers,3-5 micron,self-healing optical,melt processible
abstract: ABSTRACT:Materials utilized for 3-5 micron IR optics, have historically been limited to chalcogenide glasses and semiconductor crystals because organic polymers are strongly IR absorbing in this regime, due to the presence of carbon hydrogen (C-H), or other carbon-heteroatom (C-X) vibrational modes. Polymers are still desirable for these applications because they can be readily processed/molded and have proven to be a low cost, lightweight, and mechanically robust material in visible range optics. Research at the University of Arizona demonstrated that sulfur based co-polymers can provide a window of transparency in the IR range and the properties of these thermosets can be adjusted to enable processing into optical quality components. This is due to the thermal reversibility of the disulfide bonds in these polymers which endow them with thermal-healing characteristics. Chemists at Luna Innovations have identified a set of inorganic monomer components that can stabilize sulfur based thermosets without the use of hydrocarbons. These materials will be thermally pliable for ease of processing while being highly transparent in the mid-IR range due to the elimination of C-H vibrational modes. Luna will develop this polymeric platform to provide low cost, lightweight, mechanically robust components for IR optics and imaging.BENEFIT:The proposed polymeric materials development would enable a transformative and revolutionary technological advance in IR imaging science. When fully developed, the inorganic hybrid polysulfane materials will be poised for implementation and commercialization.The system will enable optical material manufacturers to produce inexpensive lenses and windows for use in IR optics and guidance systems for the Air Force and other defense agencies.The technology will initially be developed to provide optical material for US security and defence applications, however, the IR optical products will have applicability to a number of military and commercial applications.The ability to melt process IR optics will enable cost effective production of a number of telecommunication and camera products that utilize the mid-IR range. Aerospace, security and communication applications are just a few of the industries that stand to benefit from these optical polymers.

award_title: Hybrid Broadband Optical Links
research_keywords: Optical Links,SFDR,Optical route,LOCOS,Block Co Polymer,analog optical link,digital optical link
abstract: ABSTRACT: The use of optical fibers for the transport and distribution of RF signals brings the benefits of both worlds at the fingertip of the network engineer! A Hybrid Broadband Optical Link enables such heterogeneous network, an end-to-end network solution that leverages the unique features and capabilities offered by RF and optical networks. The use of an optical fiber backbone to provide high data rate interconnection between antenna base stations in broadband RF networks offers significant advantages while supporting both wired and wireless connectivity. Optical link capacity is paired with wireless mobility, and network management functions can also be shared, providing network operators with reductions in both operating expenses and capital investments; BENEFIT: Military communication systems on avionic platforms have very small size and low weight requirements. Fiber optic based links provide inherent advantages over electronic based systems due to ultra-wide bandwidth, immunity to electromagnetic interference and reduced weight. Despite the advantages provided by fiber optics, the size of an entire system is still limited by engineering tradeoffs such as the spacing required between components due to the fiber optic interfaces and the packaging size of individual components. Specifically, the required use of optical fiber between the laser and modulator limits the ability to create a compact transmit system. A standard system includes a laser, modulator and a photodiode receiver. Typically there is some active and/or passive signal processing that can be done post modulator, indicating that the laser and modulator are consecutive. Thus a small packaged integrated laser and modulator device is needed.

award_title: Multi-Layer Deep Structure NDI
address1: 3655 W Anthem Way, Ste A109-306, Anthm, AZ 85086
research_keywords: NDI,NDE,Eddy current,De-convolution,deep structure inspection,multiple layers,complex structures
abstract: ABSTRACT: This Proposal describes effort to create ENHANCED eddy current technology. Resulting Instrumentation demonstrates reliability and feasibility to inspect deep flaws in complex, multi-layered structures. With the wealth/quality of information generated by AJM's Instrumentation further processed by spatial algorithms, it will be possible to demonstrate a thorough inclusion of all structural boundary conditions and specific inspection conditions. The emphasis is on deep flaw detection development in metallic structures, thus, candidate NDI solutions will concentrate on corrosion and/or crack detection applications. It has been shown that pre-crack formation from work-hardening should also be discernible.; BENEFIT: Low cost, easily used instrumentation/methodology to establish airworthiness of aging aircraft, preventing waste; while ensuring higher reliability airframes without need for disassembly.

award_title: Recovery Methods for Unmanned Hypersonic Test Vehicles
research_keywords: hypersonic vehicle recovery,hypersonic experiment recovery,hypersonic flight test methods,Hypersonic flight data recovery
abstract: ABSTRACT:ACENT Laboratories LLC has a strong history in the area of hypersonic flight testing and understands that recovery of flight test vehicles and/or physical data memory for post-test inspection and analysis, are increasingly important for future hypersonic technology and vehicle development efforts.ACENT will build on our flight test legacy and synergistic work ongoing in a Phase II Air Force SBIR on Low Cost Hypersonic Flight Test Technology to develop innovative approaches for several categories of new and/or modified vehicle, experiment, and component/data recovery systems for hypersonic flight vehicles. Develop a concept of operations and the mission requirements for each recovery category. Identify candidate recovery concepts and perform an analysis of alternatives for each recovery category. Size at least one concept in each category to develop an understanding of how the system would integrate with a candidate vehicle in each recovery category. Develop a program plan for Phase II and beyond including analysis and testing to mature technology, validate models, reduce risk, and demonstrate capability.BENEFIT:Hypersonic weapon systems will open the door to many new capabilities for the warfighter.Applications include systems ranging from small tactical hypersonic missiles and larger high speed strike weapons to responsive space access systems and penetrating hypersonic intelligence, surveillance & reconnaissance (ISR) aircraft. Due to limitations in replicating hypersonic test conditions on the ground, wind tunnel data are augmented with flight tests to calibrate current computer models and provide data for developing improved physics based models used in hypersonic system design. While significant advances have been made in the last decade under Air Force and complementary DARPA, ONR and NASA efforts, a full spectrum of research, development, and demonstration (RD&D) activities is still required in a number of hypersonic disciplines to provide the full promise of these advanced capabilities.In most previous hypersonic flight programs, the flight test article was designed to be recovered after the flight test - only telemetry data was obtained - thus post flight inspections were not performed.If recovery had occurred, it could have provided valuable insights about the airframe and engine material/structural systems performance, scramjet engine operation, subsystem condition, and instrumentation requirements/optimal locations, as well as potentially providing advanced warning of potential system failures on subsequent flights.New methods to enable reliable and cost effective recovery and even reuse of hypersonic flight test articles would reduce risk, improve execution efficiency, and enhance vehicle design evolution. These recovery technologies would directly support DoD hypersonic technology maturation and demonstration, as well as T&E of weapon systems, and space vehicles by improved validation and verification of the system under test.

award_title: Radar Agnostic, Low Computation Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) Automatic Target Recognition (ATR)
research_keywords: SAR,ATR,ISR,Radar Agnostic,Physical Target Modeling,Target Classification,Target Identification,Compact ATR
abstract: ABSTRACT: Practical automated target recognition (ATR) capabilities for synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imagery require sustainable and easily updatable target representations as well as generalizability across different SAR sensors and operating conditions.Systems & Technology Research (STR), along with Wright State University, proposes to extend ATR algorithms being developed under the AFRL Compact Automatic Target Recognition and Sustainable Environment (CASE) and DARPA Target Recognition and Adaption in Contested Environments (TRACE) programs to develop a practical SAR ATR system characterized by the following attributes:(1) Rapid target model construction using coarse grain models that capture gross target shape and scattering features.(2) Encapsulation of the scattering peak extraction to produce a sensor agnostic representation of dominant target scattering structure. (3) Robust scattering peak descriptions using pyramid match hashing codes that are learned once per target. (4) Compact target classifier encoding using Fisher vectors. (5) Low computation complexity to match encoded templates against observed data. (6) Rapid updating of target database with new models using shared visual codebooks and variable fidelity model prediction.; BENEFIT: Our SAR ATR approach provides a number of benefits for SAR exploitation systems:(1) It enables streamlined specification of new targets by developing low fidelity physical models of the targets.Target models may be built manually or though automated 3D modeling techniques if multiple photographs of the new target are available.(2) Our approach enables improved ATR performance by increasing the fidelity of the target models, but is designed to work with a broad range of target fidelities.(3) The offline target classifier generation process optimizes discriminability across mission targets of interest.(4) Since our ATR approach is based on characterizing and matching scattering mechanisms of the target at different scales, a single target representation is used to support recognition across different SAR sensors, possibly operating with different data acquisition parameters.(5) Finally, our approach for online ATR processing requires low computation and storage complexity by virtue the compact target encoding techniques.While the SAR ATR capability is targeted for tactical platforms, there are a wide range of intelligence and security applications within the DoD community as well as for homeland security.

award_title: A Q-Band Gallium-Nitride (GaN) Solid State Power Amplifier (SSPA) Using Spatial Power Combining
research_keywords: Q-band,SSPA,GaN,Gallium-Nitride,protected communications,COTM,COTP,efficient
abstract: ABSTRACT: Mission Microwave proposes to demonstrate the feasibility of a Q-Band Solid-State Power Amplifier (SSPA) utilizing novel, compact and low-loss spatial power combining and a high-efficiency Gallium Nitride (GaN) MMIC power amplifier design to achieve more than 45W linear power with more than 35% PAE at Q-Band.Mission Microwave also proposes to fabricate and test the spatial power combiner to prove feasibility at Q-Band, and to complete a full SSPA system analysis (including thermal and mechanical design) to ensure reliable operation over temperature.; BENEFIT: The result of this effort will be an industry-leading SSPA with efficiency levels previously only achieved at Q-Band by TWTAs, with a form factor smaller and lighter than other Q-Band SSPAs, and which will maintain reliable operation over temperature. The high transmit power achieved will ensure high data rates and reliable, secure communications with Milstar and AEHF satellite constellations.This SSPA will enable reductions in size, weight, and power consumption of SatCom transmitters and is ideally suited for protected Comms-on-the-Pause (COTP) and Comms-on-the-Move (COTM) applications; this SWaP reduction can extend mission lifetimes (especially in airborne or power-limited environments), reduce fuel and transport costs, and extend mission capabilities.

award_title: Woven Graphite Fiber Heat Exchanger
research_keywords: Woven,Graphite,heat exchanger,conductivity,Thermoelectric,thermal,Air,Water
abstract: TAI proposes a heat exchanger (HEX) for a Thermoelectric Generator (TEG) based on high conductivity woven graphite fibers (900 W/mK with a mass density of 2.2 gr/cm3, more than twice as good as copper).The HEX proposed (plus TEGs) has a power density of 89 watts per kilogram (more than 2.5 times the best devices made for man portable battery charging).The heat source can be open flame or any other 320C+ source with a cold side heat sink of air or water.The very durable lightweight (217 grams) HEX can be collapsed and transported in an 8x11 envelope or back pack.Woven graphite samples will be built and tested to confirm the thermal and physical characteristics.Computational modeling will result in optimized designs for Government selection for Phase II.This advance in high conductivity woven graphite fibers material will create revolutionary new lightweight air heat exchanger products.

award_title: ADvanced Rf environment simulator for mOde 5 and IdenTification friend or foe (ADROIT)
research_keywords: RF,IFF,Power Amplifier,downconverter,Live-Virtual-Constructive,High-efficiency,High-Linearity,Mode 5
abstract: With current technology, up to 50 aircraft transmitting Mode 5 Identification Friend or Foe (IFF) can be simulated. To fulfill the needs of the Joint Scalable Tactical Emulated Network (JSTEN), the ability to simulate 1,000 aircraft is required. To achieve this goal, the NuWaves Team proposes the ADvanced Rf environment simulator for mOde 5 and IdenTification friend or foe (ADROIT) system. The ADROIT system builds on the current technology by incorporating a high linearity RF power amplifier (PA) and low-spurious RF downconverter in an improved COTS IFF simulator/stimulator. The additional RF output power from the PA, and the reduced spurious emissions from the downconverter combine to provide greater system dynamic range, for a more realistic representation of the RF environment.The technical objective of the ADROIT effort is to design, simulate, and analyze an innovative high-efficiency and high-linearity L-band PA, and a low-spurious downconverter to increase the dynamic range of a COTS IFF simulator/stimulator. Additionally, the integration plan for the PA and downconverter into the IFF simulator/stimulator, identification of the upgrades to the IFF simulator/stimulator to process up to 1,000 aircraft, and definition of the interface of the ADROIT system to the Armys JSTEN network will be completed.

award_title: Mode 5 Identification Friend or Foe (IFF) simulation and subsequent RF injection
research_keywords: Software Defined Radio,Mode 5 IFF,ADS-B,Simulation driven testing,Scalability testing of live radios
abstract: Mode 5 IFF is an aircraft identification system designed for command and control. New Mode 5 interrogators and transponders have been in development for the past few years and there is a need for comprehensive testing for the new systems and test support equipment prior to widespread deployment. This testing must be done at scale with a large number of multiple aircraft systems generating signals for the live interrogator/receiver to ensure that the IFF system can operate in several high air traffic conditions. In this SBIR proposal, we present M5WTB, a simulation based testing solution that will reduce costs for scalability testing of Mode 5 receivers. In M5WTB, an existinghigh fidelity Mode 5 simulation model will be tightly coupled with encryption and software defined radio hardware for injecting secure transmissions from 1000s of simulated tactical aircrafts at the 1090Mhz radio frequency in order to realistically stimulate Mode 5 receiver hardware. In Phase 1 of the SBIR effort, the Scalable team will undertake a study to define the concepts of operations and use cases for M5WTB along with further in-depth investigation of technical approaches that will make up the overall solution.

award_title: Energy Models of Critical Components (E-MC2)
research_keywords: Operational Energy,Energy Informed Operations,Forecasting,Prediction,Decision Making
abstract: Operational Energy (OE) is the energy, associated systems, information and processes required to train, move, and sustain forces and systems for military operations (Scholtes, 2013). Efficient OE requires effective management of energy and supply resources, including energy used by tactical power systems, generators and weapons platforms. Army Secretary Jon McHugh stated that leaders and individuals at all levels must understand how energy contributes to their respective operational roles and consider it in planning decisions and daily behaviors. To address these requirements, Charles River Analytics proposes to design and demonstrate the feasibility of Energy Models of Critical Components (E-MC2), a resource monitoring, energy prediction, and decision-support tool that uses probabilistic reasoning to construct and learn models of complex, real-world systems. Under E-MC2, we will build models of energy consumption and resource usage through Figaro, a probabilistic programming language (PPL) developed by Charles River. Using E-MC2s models, Commanders in environments such as forward operating bases will receive alerts and notifications relating to possible resource consumption issues. Commanders will also use E-MC2 as an aid to best plan and manage critical quantities, subject to anticipated operating constraints and external factors.

award_title: Layer-by-Layer Multiple Antigen Nano-delivery Platform for Malaria Vaccine
research_keywords: nanoparticle,layer-by-layer,multiple antigen,nano-delivery,MALARIA VACCINE
abstract: Developing a safe and effective malaria vaccine remains the hope for reducing the spread and resurgence of the disease.In recent years, vaccine research has broadened with subunit protein, and DNA vaccines due to their inherent safety, simpler storage and easier production at the expense of attenuated and inactivated organism based approaches. RTS, S/AS01, the most advanced subunit vaccine, has undergone phase III clinical trials. However, their efficacy results are relatively low (30% to 50%). Due to the subunit protein weak immunogenicity, often necessitate advanced delivery vectors or adjuvants. Recent progress in the design of synthetic nanoparticles that can stimulate immune system opened up a new area of vaccine development, however with limited successes in malaria vaccine preventing these candidates going into clinical trials. These approaches failed to overcome the inherent drawbacks of subunit vaccines as well as failed to address the unique and complex ability to infect hosts at multistage of its life cycle with varying antigens present at the parasite particle surface. Luna proposes a novel nano enabled malaria vaccine which will induce long-lived protective immune responses by targeting multiple epitopes at each of its unique life stages through precisely engineered, staged release of antigens and/or adjuvants.

award_title: Synthetic Megacity Representation in Army Modeling and Simulation (M&amp;S) Environments
research_keywords: urban terrain,web services,Service Oriented Architecture,Patterns of Life,Live Virtual Constructive
abstract: As populations continue to swell and migrate into urban areas, megacities have emerged that exert emergent complex issues.These cities that that support populations of greater than 10 million people have density and complexity that greatly surpasses what is typically found in LVC simulations.A representation of megacities in simulation is clearly important to training, doctrine development, and analysis simulation communities to allow simulation of real world conditions in these unique environments.Fundamentally representation of megacities requires significant advances in simulation technology in many inter-related dimensions.These include high entity densities within the simulation, complex multi-level urban terrain representation and reasoning, critical infrastructure and patterns of life support, and lifecycle tool support.To address these complex requirements, StackFrame proposes to leverage its Blended Simulation Internal Research and Development (IR&D) effort that already integrates dense urban terrain generated via StackFrames Magrathea terrain generation tool, with a Patterns of Life simulation with a next generation Service Oriented Architecture (SOA) based interoperability platform called Osseus.Together, these capabilities provide a Testbed that can easily be integrated with existing Army LVC simulations to research enhancements necessary to support a full Megacity capability.

award_title: Laser Protection for Day Cameras
research_keywords: laser protection,day cameras,CROWS,optical limiters
abstract: Looking at tank architectures over the past 30 years, one thing is obvious; tanks are now studded with optical sights and sensors.Instead of a few periscopes or vision blocks, modern-day tanks have a number of sensors for driving, aiming the gun and controlling a remote weapon.Next-generation tanks and fighting vehicles will have an even greater reliance on optics and sensor systems.The proliferation of multiple laser wavelengths presents a significant danger to ground vehicle vision systems, especially day camera sensors like the one used on the CROWS system.One way to protect viewing systems against fixed frequency lasers is to use narrow band spectral line rejection filters at the known laser wavelengths, attenuating incident laser energy at these wavelengths, thus preventing laser radiation from damaging the sensor. As the number of possible laser wavelengths increases, this approach becomes less practical, because for each wavelength blocked, more and more visible light is attenuated until the system is well-blocked, but useless as a visual system.Our approach is to leverage work being done at AFRL, SA Photonics, and Debye Research in developing a solid state limiter.We have chosen two different materials approaches, which should serve to minimize risk.

award_title: Nonlinear Optical Threat Protection Technologies for Daytime Cameras
research_keywords: Nonlinear optic,Electro-optic,EO Modulator,RF Photonics,additive manufacturing,nanocomposite,GRIN,gradient index optic
abstract: To protect daytime cameras against laser threats, new, innovative first-order (linear) and third-order (nonlinear) optical materials and optical systems will be designed to provide protection against both continuous-wave (CW) and pulsed lasers operating throughout the wavelength range of common daytime and low-light-level imaging cameras (400 nm through 1100 nm). The approach is based on optical-grade nanocomposites that allow for improved optical performance in compact optical assemblies while also providing nonlinear-optical (NLO) protection. The technologies we use to realize this new capability include: optical nanocomposite materials, new approaches to additive manufacturing (AM), and freeform GRIN optical engineering.NLO materials will be synthesized and their properties measured. Then, NLO lenses will be fabricated and tested. The wavefront distortion, point-spread function, modulation transfer function, transmission, haze, etc., will be tested in the laboratory, and optical-limiting-performance testing will be compared to theoretical analysis.

award_title: High Speed Surface Thermocouples Interface to Wireless Transmitters
research_keywords: High speed thermocouple,wireless telemetry,harsh environment measurement,engine telemetry,High Temperature
abstract: This project will enhance existing telemetry and thermocouple technology to develop a faster, harsh environment wireless telemetry system and an ultra sensitive, high speed, surface thermocouple for surface temperature measurements on the crown of a diesel piston.Three different state-of-the-art thermocouple methods will be explored to create a very low mass thermocouple junction. These methods are plasma welding, vacuum deposition, andplatinum laser deposition.Each will be evaluated for reaction speed with targeted response times in the micro-second range while surviving in harsh vibration, shock, and temperature environments.It is also proposed that these thermocouples will be interfaced to a wireless telemetry transmitter on the piston which will allow the surface temperature data to be transmitted from the piston during engine operation. This will be accomplished in a running diesel engine with surface measurements on the piston crown. Each thermocouple design will be compared simultaneously on the same piston in the engine using the same wireless transmitter.IR Telemetrics currently utilizes an RF transmitter with a minimum bandwidth of 10 kHz sampling rate.Through the project development, this transmitter will be increased to 35 kHz or more.

award_title: Inline Threat Generation for Modeling and Simulation
research_keywords: radar cross section,High fidelity,Fast Method of Moments,Run Time Data Production
abstract: Technology Service Corporation (TSC) proposes to develop an innovative capability for inline generation of trajectory kinematics and IR simulation data for threat missile systems for MDA M&S applications. TSC personnel have supported NASIC and other customers with RF and IR sensor data analysis for many years, and over that time TSC personnel have acquired extensive relevant experience. In Phases I and II, TSC will apply that experience to develop software to model the kinematics and simulate IR signatures for all phases of flight inline at speeds faster than real time.In Phase I, TSC will develop requirements for the new ITG technology, demonstrate its technical merit and feasibility, and provide an initial concept for V&V. For the Phase I Option, TSC will identify interfaces and begin the process of integrating the new ITG capability with the Objective Simulation Framework (OSF), or another framework selected by MDA/DE, to provide a complete M&S system. In Phase II, TSC will develop high quality computer code for the new ITG capability, fully integrate it with the existing MDA/DE M&S system, and perform V&V testing of the new capability by comparing results with those of MDA/DEs current system.

award_title: Airborne Based Sense and Avoid (ABSAA) Sensor for Tracking Non-cooperative Aircraft for RQ-7 Shadow and Larger UAS
research_keywords: Sense-and-avoid,unmanned aerial systems,Radar,Collision Avoidance,pulse-Doppler,interferometer
abstract: TSC proposes an SAA radar system for the RQ-7 UAS by re-purposing an existing small, low-cost, multi-channel pulse-Doppler radar.This highly flexible system, when combined with a high power amplifier and a novel multi-faceted antenna concept will provide the Army with a low-risk path to an Airborne SAA system for the RQ-7 or similar UAS .The proposed system can operate day or night, in rain or fog, and will provide 360 degree non-cooperative detection and tracking of targets single-engine Cessna size and larger out to 3 nmi.

award_title: Advanced High Speed Bus Technologies for Units Under Test (UUT), Test and Evaluation
research_keywords: Automated testing,unit under test,data bus,high-speed data bus,test tools,test instrumentation,VPX,PXI
abstract: The Navy relies on automatic test systems (ATS) such as the Consolidated Automatic Support System (CASS) to save billions of dollars in maintenance costs over fragmented testing techniques, minimize aircraft downtime, and quickly re-certify avionics components. Although they are state-of-the-art, modern automatic test systems like CASS interface only with conventional data buses and are unable to support current, high-speed digital data buses. Because the latest aircraft avionics and weapons systems are now incorporating high-speed buses such as SATA, Wi-Fi, IEEE 1394 FireWire, and USB, there is an immediate need to integrate high-speed bus testing into ATS. Technology Service Corporation (TSC) proposes to develop an ATS High-Speed Bus Tester (HSBT) by leveraging the test creation flexibility of its Crane Custom Test Bench (CCTB) while remaining platform agnostic through the use of IEEE 1671 ATML abstraction. CCTB is an automatic test system currently providing radar, electronic warfare, and communications testing for the Navys ALQ-218 Tactical Jamming Receiver at the Naval Surface Warfare Center (NSWC) Crane Division. Its architecture is built upon LabVIEW Object-Oriented Programming (LVOOP) and utilizes packed libraries and XML configuration files to provide flexible building blocks for test.

award_title: Continuous High Pulse Repetition Frequency (HPRF) Mode for Anti-Access/Area Denial (A2AD)
research_keywords: High PRF radar waveform,High Pulse Repetition Frequency,High PRF radar mode,Air-to-Air radar mode,Range ambiguity,Multiple PRF radar waveform
abstract: ABSTRACT: TSC and KEYW propose to develop novel methods of increasing the detection sensitivity of air-to-air modes by using a single, long Coherent Processing Interval (CPI) that eliminates the need for multiple Pulse Repetition Frequency (PRF) waveforms. TSC will investigate three highly innovative approaches in Phase I. One approach is to coherently integrate all of the pulses from the current multiple PRF waveforms out to the maximum range of interest for enhanced radar detection performance. In other approaches, TSC will focus on tracking algorithms to resolve the inherent range ambiguities when multiple PRFs and CPIs are employed.Each of these techniques will be evaluated during the proposed Phase I effort and quantified with respect to overall target detection and tracking performance improvement, computational complexity and implementation difficulty. KEYW will provide previously collected high PRF data from their Sahara testbed on aircraft targets for algorithm development and testing. In Phase II, TSC will mature the most promising algorithm(s) and experimentally demonstrate the new High PRF techniques using a selected radar testbed. Further work includes working with a radar prime contractor to transition the algorithms into an Air Force program of record.; BENEFIT: This technology can greatly improve the detection range, angle measurement accuracy and overall tracking performance of modern fighter radars against low RCS targets in sidelobe clutter, such as for tail-chase, look-down encounters with low observable cruise missiles. This will provide fighters such as the F-15E, F-35A or future F-X 6th generation fighter with an enhanced capability to detect, track and destroy advanced low-observable threats that are currently being developed and fielded by our adversaries, and will increase the security of the US and its allies.

award_title: Automated Verification and Validation for Distributed Testing
research_keywords: External Interface Testing (EIT),distributed testing,V&V Coverage,Objective Quality Evidence (OQE),Combat Systems certification,V&V Throughput,Automated Verification and Validation (V&V)
abstract: Successful V&V of complex systems relies on a representative test environment, test data, and Subject Matter Expert (SME) manpower to investigate tough cognitive issues encountered during integration. Because many systems have interface and interoperability requirements with other systems and subsystems, SIM/STIM tools are essential for ensuring incremental combat system developments are functioning correctly. But wherever there is a lack of access to resources across test communities, SME manpower is inefficiently expended planning and significant lag in the development cycle occurs. This proposal addresses limitations by providing an Automated V&V framework for Distributed Testing (ADT) which also supports the necessary SIM/STIM to conduct testing in a variety of configurations. Our novel approach will increase SIM/STIM capability while providing an automated tool suite that leverages a Model-Based Systems Engineering (MBSE) approach. A detailed model of SQQ-89 and AEGIS enables efficient cross-organizational technical reviews and provides approval and acceptance for true Objective Quality Evidence (OQE) used for platform Certification. Our solution leverages proven products within IDTs Automated Test and Re-Test (ATRT) software suite. By leveraging these core technologies we can provide the necessary infrastructure needed to achieve the Navys automated V&V goals for distributed testing while reducing development costs.

award_title: Fusion of Multiple Motion Information Sources
research_keywords: ABI,Activities Based Intelligence,Multi-source Multi-INT fusion,Graph Analytics,Activity and Event Detection,Network Detection,4d Geo-Spatial Analytics,Hadoop Ecosystem
abstract: Our approach addresses the four Vs of big data and the four pillars, or principles, of ABI, and includes multi-INT data association and fusion, inclusive of objects and activities characterized from FMV streams.To address velocity and veracity associated with of multi-INT data sources we propose to develop a scalable graph-based analytic approach which will perform near real-time analysis of multi-INT data sources.Kinematic, contextual, and feature data can be updated in the graph as it is collected and processed.The graph accounts for the uncertainty of data without having to make hard data association decisions in the fusion process.Graphs can be extended to have fuzzy relationships between sets to account for uncertainties.Our graph-based fusion and analytics approach is extendable to more focused analyses commonly encountered by analysts at NASIC and NGA.The inclusion of 4d geo-spatial analytics will be used to combine pattern-of-life information with the results of graph searches in an intuitive way.To address the variety and volume of data we propose to architect a distributed storage and processing system that integrates graph technology.We will build on prior work that utilized the Hadoop ecosystem (HDFS, MapReduce, and Hbase).

award_title: Airborne Graph Analytics Applications for Multi-sensor Fusion and Integration
research_keywords: MULTI-INT FUSION,Graph Analytics,Graph Database,network discovery,MOVINT,WAMI,EO/IR,SIGINT
abstract: ABSTRACT: Black River Systems will develop a graph based software prototype that will demonstrate the following capabilities: (1) Capturing, maintaining, and updating a graph based representation of entity association ambiguities of an onboard integration and fusion capability for kinematic and identification sensor information; (2) An automated real time graph solver that produces the most likely set of stitched track trajectories that are consistent with all of the kinematic and identification collected up to the current time, as well as updating the entire history of tracks as new informationboth kinematic and identificationis collected and dynamically added to the graph; (3) Provide the feasibility of solving the graph that will be evaluated through the use of Government tracking metrics; and (4) Demonstrate the feasibility of performing post mission forensic analysis by combining other kinematic and identification sources based on new evidence obtained after the mission has ended.; BENEFIT: Our graphical based representation of ambiguous multi-INT associations provides a flexible graph structure that is solved in real time and preserves all target associations until future information can be used for target resolution.The real-time solver produces the best tracks on demand, but uses the un-pruned graph to determine better fused target trajectories over time as new information is added.Based on design feedback from real world operators analyzing data for network discovery, our approach builds operator confidence in in the provided solutions.Finally, post mission analysis is supported through the capability of adding other mission collections to the inflight generated graph.

award_title: MEMS IMU Solutions for Missile Defense Applications
research_keywords: MEMS IMU,MES INS,Accelerometer arrays,Gyro arrays,low drift errors
abstract: IMUs in flight systems (interceptors, airborne platforms, and space assets) are constrained by limits on size, weight, power and cost (SWaP-C), and are also exposed to severe shock and vibration during storage, transport, launch, staging, deployment and engagement. This combination of requirements has proven difficult to meet using current inertial sensor technology.Inertial sensors and IMUs based on MEMs technologies have the potential to improve upon size and cost metrics for space-constrained applications. However, MEMS based IMUs have been known to experience performance degradation while operating through stressing shock and vibration environments. This Phase I effort will demonstrate, through simulation and experiment, chip-scale isolation approaches and robust resonant MEMS sensor architectures that can operate through these harsh shock and vibration environments. The Phase II effort would then continue development to realize prototype inertial units suitable for missile defense applications.

award_title: Printable Materials with Embedded Electronics and Radio Frequency Components
research_keywords: additive manufacturing,rf connectors,AMT,printable electronics,Printed electronics,embedded electronics,Ku-band,connectors
abstract: Additive Manufacturing is a disruptive technology that has the ability to change how components are made, used and repaired. The past 10 years have seen a rapid increase in the availability of low cost 3d printers. The sophistication, quality and ease of use for these tools has been increasing rapidly while the cost is decreasing. There exists an emerging opportunity to combine printed electronics with traditional additive manufacturing to realize cost savings while increasing capability. Of special interest is the opportunity to embed RF components into additive manufacturing. We propose developing technology to embed RF components into additive manufacturing substrates. A key part of this research will be the development of RF connectors suitable for additive manufacturing fabrication while still meeting the requirements for RF operation. EngeniusMicro will use its RF simulation and modeling tools to develop designs of embedded RF components then fabricate and test these designs.

award_title: Non-Invasive Measurement of Fluid/Gas Characteristics in Harsh Environments
research_keywords: Supersonic,Sensor,non-intrusive,multi-phase,Instrumentation,Tomography,flow
abstract: The US Navy is looking for a portable, non-invasive sensor system to collect flow performance data to support routine performance assessments of Navy hardware and predictions with the computational fluid dynamics (CFD) based modeling and simulation (M&S) tools. The existing tomography imaging techniques for fluid/gas flow measurements have severe limitations to meet the above requirements. In this proposal, X-wave Innovations, Inc. (XII) outlines a novel Clamp-on Ultrasonic Tomography Imaging System (CUTIS) for non-invasive, continuous imaging/measurement of fluid/gas characteristics in a thick wall steel pipe under harsh environments. The proposed CUTIS system is based on XII-developed ultrasonic tomography imaging technology, which includes a multi-channel ultrasonic generator and receiver device and a set of tomography imaging algorithms. For the Phase I program, XII will prototype a CUTIS and demonstrate the feasibility of this technique for detecting/imaging the spatially-resolved and time-dependent multi-phase flow characteristics. For the Phase II program, XII will focus on refining the prototype system design and development with improved hardware and software. For the Phase III program, XII will focus on commercialization of the developed technology.

award_title: Lithium Battery Early Warning Fault Indication System
research_keywords: lithium battery failure detection,safety,Battery,LITHIUM,Data Fusion
abstract: Enhanced battery failure detection accuracy and reliability involves the integration of novel sensors and algorithms that are able to extract relevant information from the cells in a battery pack. This must be accomplished with minimum cost of ownership, installation, and operation. X-wave Innovations Inc. (XII), and its partners, The University of Maryland and The Boeing Company, propose to tackle this problem in a two tier approach. First, we will perform an analysis of the failure mechanisms to demonstrate the response of failed cells. We will be using our existing data, and will perform tests when necessary, taking into account multiple chemistries, the application profiles, the suite of targeted sensors, and the environment. This effort will result in the enhancement of our current data fusion algorithms, which will be tuned to the specific Navy application. Based on the previous efforts, our second step will be to develop a novel low cost SWaP embedded system that combines conventional sensors with a low-cost and low-power set of unique transducers capable of detecting battery faults reliably. By the end of Phase I our system will provide an accurate representation of the battery's safety state with technology that will require minimum installation and commissioning effort.

award_title: Non-Destructive Inspection for Repaired Integrally Bladed Disk Airfoils
research_keywords: Integrally bladed disk,repairs,Integrity Assessment,microstructure analysis,defect inspection,Acoustic microscopy,material characterization
abstract: ABSTRACT: The US Air Force seeks an innovative nondestructive evaluation (NDE) technique to assess the integrity and microstructure state of integrally bladed disk (IBD) airfoils after repairs. The IBD repair process typically involves machining away the damage portion, refilling materials using either additive type processing methods or welding a patch on it, restoring material microstructure through post heat treatment, and restore the original blade shape via machining. One big concern to the IBD repairs in the mechanical property knock-down. Therefore, a NDE technology capable of assessing the repair material microstructure and mechanical properties, as well as detecting internal and surface flaws is highly desirable. In this proposal, X-wave Innovations, Inc. (XII) outlines an innovative Quantitative Acoustic Microscopy (called QAM) technology. Phase I program is to develop a prototype system and demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed QAM technique. For the Phase II program, XII will focus on refining the prototype system design and development with improved hardware and software.For the Phase III program, XII will focus on commercializing the developed QAM technology.; BENEFIT: The proposed QAM system has many market applications in different industries such as the air and space vehicles, power generators, and advanced new material research. The total market will increase in the future because the characterization of material properties and detection of defects is essential for many important material systems. The proposed research provides a great support for improvement of the integrity and safety of repaired IBD airfoils. Such a system will benefit the enhancement of the lifetime and durability and the reduction of failure risk of the engine.

award_title: Inline Threat Generation Using FRAMES 2.0
research_keywords: M&S,MODELING AND SIMULATION,Threat Data Generation,trajectory generation,IR modeling,IR Simulation
abstract: We intend to create a software tool, The Fast Rendering Algorithm for Missile Emission Scenes, Version 2 (FRAMES 2.0), that allows for real time modeling of EO/IR plume signatures over a wide variety of threat systems and viewing platforms. The software suites foundation lies in a one-time creation of a look-up table which represents high-fidelity missile plume computations in terms of fluid flow streamlines with superimposed physical properties such as temperature, density, and species concentrations. The result is a compact and scalable (for different system and sensor parameters) representation of the multi-dimensional simulation environment. This is coupled with novel spatial morphing, field interpolation, and radiative transfer algorithms to allow FRAMES to achieve real-time performance over a wide range of threat systems.This software suite will initially be developed to address boost phase missile signatures and later extended to mid-course.It will be developed as an integrable module for MDA high-level architectures including the Objective Simulation Framework (OSF).

award_title: FRAMES-EMSIG: Missile Plume Interpolation and Rendering Software for Simulating Low-Altitude Threats in Real-Time
research_keywords: frames,Plume,signature,Database,real-time,image,model,flow field
abstract: The performance of early warning and missile defense optical sensors and their associated detection and tracking algorithms can be robustly evaluated using hardware-in-the-loop (HWIL) testing technology.This requires high-frame rate (~400 Hz) simulated imagery of the highly dynamic threat missile system.There is a need for an engineering-level method to provide on-demand, real-time, realistic plume imagery to the HWIL scene generator.Spectral Sciences, Inc. and Kinetics, Inc. propose to extend an existing high-altitude plume flow filed morphing and real-time plume imaging system, the Fast Rendering Algorithm for Missile Emission Scenes (FRAMES) to apply to low altitude missile systems.The key idea in the FRAMES approach is that one interpolates between pre-computed flow fields, and then generates an image based on the interpolated flow field, rather than interpolating between pre-computed images. This project focuses on morphological interpolation ofthe low-altitude Enhanced Missile Signature (E-MSIG) plume flow field database, and rendering high-frame rate imagery using the GPU-based SPIDER radiative transfer code. In Phase I we will develop and demonstrate the FRAMES-EMSIG algorithms necessary to generate missile plume signatures targeting a 50 Hz frame rate for a representative threat system.

award_title: Hypervelocity Materials Research Testbed
research_keywords: Materials Characterization,hypersonic,non-local thermodynamic equilibrium,Radiative Transfer,Computational Fluid Dynamics,Ceramic Matrix Composites,carbon-carbon composites
abstract: ABSTRACT: The characterization of novel thermal protection system (TPS) materials is key to the mission success of future hypersonic vehicles.Non-intrusive methods, based on spectroscopic signatures, can provide information on the state of the TPS materials and surrounding shock layer.However, the close coupling of the TPS material response with the high-temperature gas dynamics and finite-rate chemistry create a strong non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (NLTE) environment that must be taken into account to properly interpret measurements.To date, no end-to-end simulation tool exists that connects the advanced material response, chemistry, gas flow, and particulates to the electro-optic infrared (EO/IR) signature.The goal of this R&D by Spectral Sciences, Inc. is to develop new simulation tools to create a material characterization testbed with EO/IR signatures.Phase I would provide a proof of principle framework for the simulation tool, with focus on evaluating material characterization from spectroscopic measurements of emitting surfaces, NLTE gas products, and embedded micro-capsules.In Phase II, the software will be further extended and validated to enable a better understanding of advanced TPS material response.Finally, it will be used to update material thermodynamic models for a wide range of advanced TPS materials.; BENEFIT: The proposed toolset and upgraded simulation capabilities will have wide application for hypersonic flow problems, including the development of military hypersonic vehicles and their TPS materials and the modeling of reentry flows for missile defense. The software will enable characterization of advanced materials under a wide range of hypersonic conditions.Further applications could include development of design sensor concepts for intercept and tracking of current and future hypersonic and reentry weapons systems.Military applications also include analysis of intelligence data.Furthermore, work on validating and hardening the proposed toolset will aid other DoD programs that use the underlying computational fluid dynamics and radiation transport libraries.Commercial applications consist of design of reentry systems for NASA and commercial transport systems. In addition, the proposed software complements existing commercial continuum fluid dynamics software, providing gas/flame diagnostics modeling tools for high temperature flows.

award_title: Physics Based Data Reconciliation of FTIR Data for Retrieval of BMI Composite Heat Damage State
research_keywords: Composite,incipient,Heat Damage,nondestructive inspection,FTIR,bismaleimide,BMI,NDI
abstract: ABSTRACT: Composite materials in aircraft are susceptible to heat damage.There is an urgent need to detect and quantify heat damage at an early stage (incipient heat damage) using non-destructive methods.Handheld Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) instruments represent a promising means to detect and quantify heat damage.Spectral Sciences, Inc. together with Aurora Flight Sciences propose a systematic acquisition of FTIR spectra from composites with varying degrees of heat damage coupled with a physics-based post-processing of those spectra.The Infrared Non-destructive Spectral Procedure for Composite Testing (INSPCT) approach will relate physically and chemically meaningful interpretations of FTIR spectra to mechanical strength and heat-damage state of the material. The key enabling technologies are the application of sophisticated retrieval and spectral abundance analyses of measured FTIR spectra and physics-based interpretation techniques based in fundamental optical properties to extract spectral fingerprints of heat damage from the signal.The product will take measured FTIR spectra and return the damage state referenced to ASTM tests.; BENEFIT: The successful product will interpret spectral features of BMI composite material measured with a handheld FTIR and relate it to ASTM test-referenced local material strength.The underlying database of FTIR measurements and ASTM-referenced local strengths will also be available as a product.A software module embedded in the handheld FTIR processor will provide the inspector prompt readings of the extent if any of heat damage to the composite.The approach we take should be adaptable to any composite material system, so that the product could be applied to FTIR interrogation of the chemical state (be it heat damage, degree of cure, etc.) of any resin bearing composite.The approach uses algorithms from remote sensing, and may be conformable in the future to a standoff inspection that could survey a large area in one acquisition.

award_title: Innovative Technologies for Detection and Discrimination of Surface and Buried Explosive Hazards
research_keywords: LWIR Polarimetry,Explosive Threat Detection,image fusion
abstract: Detecting buried in road or roadside explosive threats is a major problem facing the Army on todays battlefield. Recent studies have shown that Long Wave Infrared (LWIR) imaging polarimeters can detect these threats; however, the implementation of the polarimeters has not been traceable to a ruggedized, field ready imaging system. Guidestar Optical Systems proposes to develop an imaging LWIR polarimeter to detect disturbed earth (a signature of buried explosives) and man-made objects on the roadside. The implementation of Guidestars polarimeter will be suitable for use with dynamic scenes and a vibrating/moving platform. We will develop a Phase I bench top prototype sensor suite (consisting of the LWIR polarimeter, a visible imaging camera, and a near IR imaging camera) and perform initial testing with this suite. The visible and NIR cameras will provide high-resolution images to enhance the detection capability of the LWIR polarimeter. The Phase I option program will expand the testing to include threat detection with cluttered scenes and backgrounds to provide a robust proof of concept demonstration as well as identify the key design features required for the Phase II field capable prototype sensor.

award_title: Holographic Imaging to Support Air-to-Air, High-Bandwidth, Image-Based, Active Tracking
research_keywords: digital holography,Active Tracking,speckle mitigation,scintillation mitigation,Image processing
abstract: ABSTRACT: Guidestar Optical Systems proposes using digital holography to track an extended target in the presence of scintillation and speckle. Speckle is mitigated using an iterative metric optimization method on received images and then time averaged to remove scintillation effects. A wave-optics simulation will be performed in Phase I to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed system, shifting to hardware in Phase II.; BENEFIT: High energy laser systems require actively illuminated targets for fine tracking purposes.This active illumination causes speckle and scintillation artifacts, which Guidestar proposes to mitigate using digital holographic imaging.This digital holographic imaging technique allows for decreased illuminator power, which will significantly enhance the size, weight, and power of the tracking system, a critical performance metric for airborne systems.In addition to the active tracking application, high resolution imagery produced by the digital holographic imaging technique enables target identification, kill assessment, three dimensional imaging, fine detail extraction in surveillance missions, and target material composition.Industrial applications include defect detection and identification, as well as stress and failure detection and analysis.Potential commercial applications include three dimensional video recording for the next generation of three dimensional video projection systems.

award_title: Contextual Reasoning for Object Identification
research_keywords: ballistic missile,Context,target detection,sensor fusion,early warning systems,Radar,statistical relationship learning,estimation theory
abstract: This Small Business Technology Transfer project will develop a mathematical framework and enabling technologies for context-aware target classification and selection for missile defense systems in the presence of counter-measures and clutter in realistic scenarios. Based on statistical relationship learning (SRL) methodology, the proposed framework can reason simultaneously about multiple entries in the threat complex even in the presence of corrupted or missing sensory data. The Phase-I effort will include; development of context-based classification framework based on SRL, quantitative and qualitative evaluation of the proposed technologies, and demonstration of proof of concept using simulated data from multiple use-cases. The project will benefit from Novateur Teams expertise in the areas of radar systems, multi-sensor data and decision fusion, adaptive context-aware system, distributed sensor network and estimation theory.  Approved for Public Release  16-MDA-8620 (1 April 16)

award_title: Real Time Computer Vision
research_keywords: background separation,object detection,Computer Vision,real-time sensor exploitation,automated visual surveillance
abstract: This SBIR Phase I project will demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of efficient background separation technologies that enable real-time computer vision in mobile sensors and devices. The proposed technologies use advanced mathematical models and subspace estimation algorithms that are several orders-of-magnitude faster than the state-of-the-art methods. Therefore, the proposed technologies do not require hardware optimizations or special computational architectures to achieve real-time performance on a variety of mobile processors. Furthermore, as opposed to many state-of-the-art approaches, they enable background separation on videos from freely moving sensors. The Phase I effort will include; development of proposed background separation algorithms and its enabling technologies, quantitative and qualitative evaluation of the proposed technologies, and demonstration of proof of concept using real-world data from multiple use-cases. The project will benefit from Novateur Teams expertise in background subtraction, automated visual surveillance, and adaptable sensor exploitation.

award_title: Cognitive Processing and Exploitation of 3D Laser Imaging Detection and Ranging (LIDAR) Imagery Data
research_keywords: lidar,target detection and classification,Deep Learning,convolutional networks,3D vision,Cognitive Systems,visual attention,Saliency
abstract: ABSTRACT: This SBIR Phase I project proposes a hierarchical visual processing system and attention-based mechanisms based on novel 3D convolutional neural networks to enable robust and efficient detection and classification of objects in 3D LIDAR imagery. Our approach models the ventral pathway of the visual cortex and addresses many limitations of the state-of-the-art solutions that perform exhaustive search for the targets of interest and rely on pre-designed features. Instead, the proposed framework uses bottom-up and top-down attentional mechanisms to improve the efficiency of the framework and enable incorporation of prior models and available context for efficient performance. In addition, instead of using hard-coded features, the proposed approach is capable of learning hierarchical invariant 3D feature representations that are object class independent from training datasets. The Phase I effort will include; development of biologically inspired 3D deep learning framework for 3D LIDAR data, fusion-of-attention mechanisms to identify salient regions, implementation of the software as open-source library, quantitative and qualitative evaluation of the proposed technologies, and demonstration of proof of concept using real-world data from multiple use-cases.; BENEFIT: Autonomous unmanned vehicles (UxVs) have proven to be critical assets for intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance as well as remote sensing systems. Equipped with commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS) EO/IR and LIDAR sensors, they are capable of providing high resolution 3D mapping of wide geospatial areas and generate a large amount of data. For example, new COTS LIDAR sensors are capable of producing between 20,000 to 200,000 points per second for large range systems and more than a million points per second for short-range systems. The availability of large volumes of information-rich sensor data poses unique challenges to analysts for timely data exploitation. The technologies proposed here would advance the state-of-the-art in the exploitation of LIDAR sensors and will enable robust and efficient detection and classification of objects-of-interest in 3D LIDAR imagery. The proposed technologies will also provide a natural framework for combining context information from other sensors (e.g. EO/IR) for improved target detection and classification. The proposed technologies have wide ranging commercial and defense applications that include:Multi-sensor Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance Systems.Autonomous surveying systems for urban planningDamage analysis tools for disaster assessment, response and recovery.The proposed technologies advance the state of the art in the DoD S&T emphasis area of AutonomyThe proposed detection and classification technology will result in improved manned and un-manned sensor exploitation systems.

award_title: Compact Optical Inertial Reference Unit for High Energy Laser System Line-of-Sight Stabilization
research_keywords: Stabilization,OIRU,IMU,precision pointing,INS,LOS/INS,Navigation
abstract: ABSTRACT: CDI is proposing a tactical OIRU design based on a modified production IMU combined with our LOS/INS module.The combination of production IMU hardware in a compact OIRU design, tailored to the tactical vibration environment, provides a competitive OIRU design on a $/rejected jitter basis.; BENEFIT: The anticipated benefit to the Airforce is that CDI's tactical OIRU will enable precision pointing and micro-radian stabilization using IMU technology currently in production. This will provide a near term OIRU that will perform reliably in the most severe tactical base motion environments. The implementation of a OIRU and an integrated INS eliminates the need for an external GPS/INS, reducing beam director implementation costs substantially.

award_title: Fusion of Kinematic and Identification (ID) Information
research_keywords: MULTI-INT FUSION,multi-target tracking,multi hypothesis tracking (MHT),high value target (HVT),extended correlation,track stitching,hypothesis management
abstract: ABSTRACT: To improve the tracking and pattern analysis of high value targets (HVTs), a technique for associating and fusing large quantities of kinematic data with temporally sparse, but highly informative, target ID information is required. Specifically, there is a need to develop a data association algorithm that will connect highly informative target ID observations with kinematic tracks in order to estimate the set of likely trajectories that an HVT could have traveled between these ID observations. The primary challenges include: (1) ambiguity and gaps in tracks over extended time periods, (2) high rate and volume of kinematic data to be processed, and (3) use of multi-INT classification data with varying feature spaces, uncertainty models, and ambiguities. Lakota Technical Solutions, Inc. proposes the Boundary Value and Retrospective Correlator (BVARC) algorithm for association of multi-INT classification and kinematic data with temporally sparse ID information. This approach provides an O(N) storage size scalability for track hypotheses, O(N log(N)) computational complexity for data association, and leverages a Technology Readiness Level (TRL) 6 technology to quantify the consistency and conflict between multi-INT classification data. The BVARC provides a tractable capability to identify and rank the set of trajectories traveled by an HVT for large-scale tracking problems.; BENEFIT: The DoD encounters many problems that require the tracking, classification, and analysis of target behavior over extended time periods far beyond the update intervals of a sensor, including: (a) high-value targets traveling in vehicles on land, (b) ballistic missile handoff between over-the-horizon (OTH) sensors, (c) maritime vessels traveling great distances with large gaps in sensor coverage, (d) submarines with intermittent detections, and (e) orbiting satellites that performing maneuvers during large gaps in sensor coverage. Each of these examples requires the ability to maintain and evaluate trajectory hypotheses over extended periods of time with feasible storage and computational requirements. Lakotas proposed BVARC is a generalized approach that can be employed in all of these domains with computational feasibility in large-scale tracking environments where large numbers of hypotheses are inevitable. As a result, BVARC has a large canvas of potential transition targets within the Air Force, other DoD, and potentially private commercial domains.

award_title: Airborne Multistatic Anti-Submarine Warfare Operator Target Detection and Discrimination System Workload Reduction
research_keywords: Multistatic,Workload Reduction,Clutter Reduction,Tactical Decision Aid,Data Fusion,information superiority,sonar automation
abstract: To address the need for techniques and tools which consolidate information from multistatic-sonobuoy-field contact reports and provide the operator with the capability to rapidly find and focus on target detections, Applied Research in Acoustics LLC (ARiA) will develop an Automated Grid Integration (AGI) P-8A Applications Based Architecture (ABA) compatible software application to reduce clutter and false alarms for the Multistatic Active Coherent (MAC) system. The AGI application will employ signal-integration fusing algorithms across a geospatial grid array using qualitative data-filtering algorithms and intuitive Human Machine Interface (HMI) displays to improve the P-8As Acoustic Operator performance in identifying valid MAC-system detections. AGI will employ a common geospatial grid that will be used to define multiple arrays of filtered detection data integrated over time. The Phase I effort will (1) research and investigate the suitability and feasibility of AGI to significantly improve an operators ability to determine target detection(s) using simulated data at representative rates, (2) develop and demonstrate a conceptual model or process for an Airborne Multistatic Anti-Submarine Warfare Operator Target Detection and Discrimination System which consolidates information from the contact reports.

award_title: Compressive Estimation and Reconstruction of Transmission Loss (TL) and Environment (CERTEN)
research_keywords: Tactical Decision,compressive sensing,Airborne ASW,ASW Operator Workload Reduction,aids,mission planning tools,Sparse Estimation,TRANSMISSION LOSS,Estimation
abstract: To provide a robust capability for transmission-loss (TL) estimation that enables discrimination of clutter from possible target echoes, ARiA will develop and demonstrate the feasibility of the Compressive Estimation and Reconstruction of TL and Environment (CERTEN) algorithm and software for multistatic Anti-Submarine Warfare (ASW) sonars to decrease the workload of P-3/P-8 Maritime Patrol and Reconnaissance Aircraft (MPRA) ASW acoustic-sensor operators by reducing or eliminating clutter from Multistatic Active Coherent (MAC) contacts. ARiA will develop and evaluate (1) dictionary learning from measured and simulated acoustical data, (2) sparse estimation and reconstruction from measured TL data, and (3) TL-based clutter suppression using estimated TL grids. The Phase I effort will (1) research, design, and develop the CERTEN algorithm and software as a TL-estimation and clutter-suppression capability for multistatic ASW; (2) demonstrate that CERTEN can feasibly meet Navy needs by robustly estimating TL in a wide range of locations and environmental conditions to enhance operator performance through improved search-mission planning and TL-based clutter rejection that reduces false-alarm rate (FAR) and operator work load; and (3) establish that CERTEN can be developed into a useful product for the Navy that is compatible with TDAs and tactical systems in use by the Airborne ASW community.

award_title: Thermally Efficient Emitter Technology for Advanced Scene/Simulation Capability in Hardware in the Loop Testing
research_keywords: Infrared,emitter,Array,Digital micromirror device,DMD
abstract: Optical Sciences Corporation proposes to demonstrate the feasibility of, and present a plan for, the development of an advanced thermally efficient emitter technology.The proposed concept offers the potential for a high frame rate, flickerless, broadband, large format (4k x 4k), emitter array with high apparent temperatures and efficient thermal emission. This emitter array IR projector system will be suitable for use in government and prime contractor HWIL simulation facilities. This emitter array andassociated technology is designed to meet or exceed the objectives outlined in the SBIR MDA15-014 topic.(Approved for Public Release 15-MDA-8482 (17 November 15))

award_title: Maintenance Data Collection from Non-Networked Automatic Test Equipment
research_keywords: data analysis,Alternate Network Connectivity,data capture
abstract: The proposed solution is designed to directly support the USAFs Complex of the Future goals including 100% data availability, increased (quality) part availability, an efficient depot, and an effective workforce. It will enable 100% data availability through, not only the collection of the ATE health and test results data via a dedicated ATE network, but the aggregation, analytics, and search capabilities of a central data repository. The increased efficiency of the depot can be realized through the integration of Condition Based Maintenance (CBM) methodologies that can be built upon the new data repository. The solution will promote an effective workforce by lessening the overall demands of data collection through the reduction of the required manual data collection effort and time. Finally, increased quality part availability can be achieved in three ways. The first way is through the increased availability of the ATE itself.The second is through the accurate historical tracking of ATE operational quality and individual serialized parts being evaluated. The third way is through the use of an untapped data source contained within many of the ATEs.

award_title: Shock Hardened Inertial Measurement Unit (SHIMU)
research_keywords: Thermal Battery,Anode,CATHODE,Energy Storage,electrodes,Electrolyte,Molten salt
abstract: The team of ATA and SNL is developing the Shock Hardened Inertial Measurement Unit (SHIMU) with robust MEMS inertial components that can survive severe shock and vibration loads and operate effectively during the launch sequence and high-G maneuvers typical of missile defense applications.Enabling technologies include very high aspect ratio proof mass suspensions that provide high out-of-plane motion rejection and reduced quadrature error.We have developed a motion sensing device that promises sensitivity levels on the order of femtometers, which allows the proof mass suspension system to be made much stiffer while retaining the ability to detect small deflections.SHIMU will employ temperature stabilization through micro-ovenization to improve bias and scale factor stability.The thermal and mechanical isolation afforded by this approach will help alleviate misalignment problems arising from structural stresses associated with the assembly and mounting processes as well as those created by temperature variations occurring after assembly.The range of motion of the proof mass will be constrained to the linear region of the sensor by the method of force rebalancing using an improved electrostatic actuation technology that can generate high forces with lower voltages, significantly reducing force related errors.

award_title: Bright Star
research_keywords: Bright Star,Mitigate Speckle and Scintillation,Super Continuum Fiber Laser,Optimal Configurable Power Scaling,High Bandwidth Tracking,Frame Rate Independent,Low SWaP-C,Variable Divergence
abstract: ABSTRACT: ATA will develop the Bright Star illuminator concept to mitigate speckle and scintillation by applying spectrally diverse, high brightness, fiber laser technology, in a spatially diverse transmitter array, to afford optimal, configurable, power scaling, relevant to the range requirements for specific tracking and Intelligence Sensing and Reconnaissance (ISR) objectives.The Air Force is seeking methods, hardware approaches, and laboratory demonstration concepts to mitigate speckle and scintillation noise observed in relevant actively illuminated tracking.The Bright Star research will demonstrate that speckle and scintillation mitigation can be achieved without the need for temporal averaging, thereby enabling the highest possible tracking bandwidth.Bright Star will leverage the wavelength dependence of speckle and scintillation to develop a modeling approach for our hardware concept development that affords frame rate independent mitigation of speckle and scintillation noise.ATAs innovative approach leverages commercially available Super Continuum White Light fiber laser technology.Exploiting Super Continuum fiber laser technology affords a high-value, low-risk, rapid technical maturation approach to validate spectral diversity efficiency in reducing speckle and scintillation noise.;
